title: Cramer's Rule for 2x2 Systems
text:
Cramer’s Rule is a method that uses determinants to solve systems of equations that have the same number of equations as variables.
Consider a system of two linear equations in two variables.
$$a_1 x+b_1 y=c_1$$
$$a_2 x+b_2 y=c_2$$
|newline| The solution using Cramer's Rule is given as
$$x= rac{D_x}{D}=$$ |(c_1,b_1),(c_2,b_2)|/|(a_1,b_1),(a_2,b_2)|, $$D 
eq 0;$$
$$y= rac{D_y}{D}=$$ |(a_1,c_1),(a_2,c_2)|/|(a_1,b_1),(a_2,b_2)|, $$D 
eq 0;$$
If we are solving for $$x$$, the $$x$$ column is replaced with the constant column. If we are solving for $$y$$, the $$y$$ column is replaced with the constant column.

title: Determinant of 2x2 Matrix
text: The determinant of a 2×2 matrix, given $$A=\begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix}$$ is defined as $$det(A)=a d-c b$$.

title: Determinant of Zero
text: A determinant of zero means that either the system has no solution or it has an $$infinite$$ number of solutions. We use the process of elimination to see which one.

title: Elimination
text: When there are like terms in both equation, we can add or subtract the common terms so that we are left with only one variable that we can solve.
